Award.AwardTitle: Field Testing Raman Microspectroscopic Therobarometers in Garnet
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will use a novel analytical technique - confocal Raman microspectroscopy - to investigate the physical character of natural mineral inclusions inside their host minerals. This information is important for understanding the physical conditions under which rocks form, and the degree to which rocks retain that information during cooling. This work will also identify whether measurements are biased by inclusion geometry or high temperatures of rock formation. If successful, Raman microspectroscopy could revolutionize investigations of the pressures and temperatures of rock formation, which are important to a variety of fields including igneous, metamorphic, and ore-forming processes. We may also identify what holds rocks together, which would have broad applications to materials synthesis science. Funding will support the research and training of a new PhD student. This research will be used to leverage educational opportunities in undergraduate and graduate courses at Boise State University, which reaches a different student demographic than other American universities.

The central focus of this project is to critically test the Quartz-in-Garnet (QuiG) barometer and Zircon-in-Garnet (ZiG) thermometer. Three main questions include: (1) Is there a threshold temperature above which thermoba-Raman-try fails in garnet? (2) Are inclusion underpressures reliably preserved? and (3) Does inclusion shape matter? Five basic sets of data will address these questions: (1) Raman spectra will be collected over a range of pressure-temperature (P-T) conditions to see whether garnet reliably encodes entrapment P-T conditions over all P-T space. Application of ZiG is particularly important in identifying whether entrapment T's are preserved. (2) Chemical zoning will be investigated around inclusions to see whether pressures induced by expanding or contracting inclusions induce chemical modification to garnet molar volumes. (3) Raman spectra will be collected for low-P, high-T rocks, where QuiG underpressures are expected, and compared against expected Pincl. (4) Pincl (Raman peak shifts) in quartz and zircon inclusions with a range of aspect ratios will be spatially mapped at a Âµm scale. (5) Infrared spectra will be collected on sub-mm spots in garnet to identify OH contents and possible impact of hydrolytic weakening on garnet strength. These data will test assumptions that underpin applications of thermoba-Raman-try and empirically identify the region of P-T space over which the method can be applied to inclusions in garnet. Data will also permit expanded research into the P-T conditions of igneous and ore deposit formation, independent of chemical or thermodynamic models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to develop methods of using Raman spectroscopic microanalysis of mineral inclusions to determine the pressure (P) and temperature (T) at which a host mineral overgrew its inclusions. Key examples are quartz and zircon inclusions inside garnets for determining the P-T conditions of garnet formation. This work is especially important for understanding processes attending continental collisions, but has extensions to conditions of igneous melt crystallization and formation of ore deposits. Our work focused on collecting Raman spectroscopic data, especially to ensure precise and accurate measurements. This work involved close collaboration between the Department of Geosciences and the Department of Materials Science and Engineering. Other work emphasized collection and interpretation of inclusions for natural samples from the European Alps.

 

Our primary result is the development of an analytical protocol applicable to all Raman microscopes. We evaluated the inclusion response to laser wavelength, laser intensity, and duration of analysis. In principle these can all cause heating of inclusions, and indeed in one case a zircon inclusion exploded when intensity and duration of analysis exceeded a threshold. Most significant to routine analysis is that Raman microscopes exhibit short-term stability (less than 0.1 cm-1/hr drift) over several hours punctuated by that are both large (≥1 cm-1) and abrupt (in minutes). If jumps are not recognized, application of Raman spectroscopy to the recovery of mineral formation pressures can be severely compromised. This primary work has been presented at an international meeting (Cizina et al., 2019) and constitutes the thesis of MS student Mayara Cizina, who will be producing a manuscript on this for publication.

 

Ancillary research endeavors and outcomes, mainly directed towards applications to quantify pressure-temperature conditions of rocks and tectonics, include:

Application of Raman spectroscopy for determining pressures of entrapment. This work summarizes recent advances in the use of Raman spectroscopic microanalysis for investigating metamorphism and the tectonics of subduction zones.

Improvement of thermometers both in precision and accuracy. This work provides guidelines for data analysis and data processing, plus a refined calibration of a key thermometer.

A new synthesis of the structural evolution of collisional belts, and determination of temperature-time histories in the Himalaya. This work improves interpretations of how mountain belts develop during continental collisions

 

This grant directly supported the focused research and educational activities of 2 PhD students, 2 MS students and 1 undergraduate at Boise State University, plus 2 visiting PhD students at the University of Maryland and at Washington State University.
